FedXGBoost: Privacy-Preserving XGBoost for Federated Learning

Nhan Khanh Le1111Contact Author    Yang Liu2    Quang Minh Nguyen4    Qingchen Liu1    Fangzhou Liu3    Quanwei Cai2 &Sandra Hirche1 1Chair of Information-Oriented Control, Technical University of Munich
2Security Research, Bytedance Inc.
3Chair of Automatic Control Engineering, Technical University of Munich
4 Department of EECS, Massachusetts Institute of Technology liuyang.fromthu@bytedance.com, caiquanwei@bytedance.com, {nhankhanh.le, qingchen.liu, fangzhou.liu, hirche}@tum.de, nmquang@mit.edu
Abstract

Federated learning is the distributed machine learning framework that enables collaborative training across multiple parties while ensuring data privacy. Practical adaptation of XGBoost, the state-of-the-art tree boosting framework, to federated learning remains limited due to high cost incurred by conventional privacy-preserving methods. To address the problem, we propose two variants of federated XGBoost with privacy guarantee: FedXGBoost-SMM and FedXGBoost-LDP. Our first protocol FedXGBoost-SMM deploys enhanced secure matrix multiplication method to preserve privacy with lossless accuracy and lower overhead than encryption-based techniques. Developed independently, the second protocol FedXGBoost-LDP is heuristically designed with noise perturbation for local differential privacy, and empirically evaluated on real-world and synthetic datasets.

1 Introduction

As a distributed machine learning (ML) model, FL benefits from the variety of multiple data holders and facilitates collaborative training. Its widespread usage can be found in credit card fraud detection Yang et al. (2019b), banking prediction Shingi (2020), and health care application by Xu and Wang (2019). Nevertheless, participants of a FL model are required to share the knowledge of their data, leading to the threat of privacy leakage. Privacy-preserving in Federated Learning (FL) is thus one of the key challenges. Several anonymization approaches that cover users’ identification are shown to be insufficient Narayanan and Shmatikov (2006). Furthermore, the European Union recently imposed General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) to increase the privacy protection of user’s private data. Therefore, any FL framework must satisfy privacy-preserving criteria while offering high-quality ML service. An informative overview of privacy-preserving under FL is provided in Yang et al. (2019a).

XGBoost - Gradient boosted decision trees by Chen and Guestrin (2016) is a novel tree ensemble model that achieves state-of-the-art results on a variety of machine learning problems. In this paper, we aim to bring the benefits of XGBoost to the FL settings with privacy-preserving guarantees. Many existing work of FL-based gradient boosting methods require different types of encryption-based protocols: homomorphic encryption Liu et al. (2020) Aono et al. (2016) Fang et al. (2020a), secret-sharing Fang et al. (2020b) and locality sensitivity hashing Li et al. (2019), all of which result in significant communication/computation overhead. Applying Homomorphic Encryption (HE) , Cheng et al. (2019) provides SecureBoost that offers high degree of privacy-preserving but requires high communication cost. Other approaches utilize Differential Privacy (DP) and perform the analysis directly with the perturbed data as studied in Li et al. (2021) , Shi et al. (2021). Despite the reduction in training time, the model suffers accuracy loss by the injected noise. Our approach deviates from all the previous work. We study a protocol that has lossless accuracy and achieves a compromise between model complexity and privacy-preserving. We first formulate the evaluation of splitting score, the major step requiring privacy guarantee in XGBoost, as the multiplication of a categorical matrix and a vector, and then deploy a modified version of secure matrix multiplication (SMM) introduced in Karr et al. (2007). We show that if SMM is naively applied, due to its categorical entries the privacy guarantee of the matrix can be violated.We further point out the analogous scenario of privacy leakage that could be inherent in HE, yet neglected by the literature. To address the challenge, we enhance the SMM protocol to provide additional deniability and propose FedXGBoost-SMM, XGBoost for FL over vertically partitioned data with privacy-preserving guarantee. In addition, utilizing noise perturbation with local differential privacy (LDP), we introduce FedXGBoost-LDP, which is a heuristic for practical perspective. Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    FedXGBoost-SMM: a linear algebra based approach designed to achieve lossless model accuracy and more efficient in comparison to HE. We vertically encode the categorical matrix and show that the extremely curious party can infer the true value of the matrix with low probability, while the overhead is negligible. We provide modifications to enhance the privacy-preserving.

  • •

    FedXGBoost-LDP: a heuristically designed protocol with LDP that yields acceptable practical results.

  • •

    Practicality: We experiment on real-world data and evaluate the utility of the heuristic FedXGBoost-LDP.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 represents the preliminaries and the problem statement. Section 3 introduces the applied privacy-preserving techniques and analyzes the potential information leakage of the proposed algorithms. Section 4 describes the procedures of FedXGBoost. The experiments and the evaluation of the protocols are provided in section 5. Section 6 concludes the study.

2.1.2 XGBoost: Regression Tree Boosting

Chen and Guestrin (2016) applied iterative optimization procedure to minimize the objective function (2). At the tt​hsuperscript𝑡𝑡ℎt^{th} iteration, new tree ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t} is constructed and contributes to the regression model. Therefore, the objective function at the tt​hsuperscript𝑡𝑡ℎt^{th} iteration is formulated as

ℒ(t)=∑i=1n(l(yi,y^i(t−1)+ft(xi))+Ω(ft)\mathcal{L}^{(t)}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(l(y_{i},\hat{y}^{(t-1)}_{i}+f_{t}(x_{i}))+\Omega(f_{t})\\ (3)

Two factors that decide the efficiency of the training process are the structure of the new tree and the leaf weights. The tree is constructed by splitting the set of users into multiple nodes and analyzing their feature data. Many splitting options are proposed according to the feature distribution. Then the optimal candidate is selected to split the instances into left and right nodes. Chen and Guestrin (2016) used the following equation to evaluate the splitting candidates

where IL,IRsubscript𝐼𝐿subscript𝐼𝑅I_{L},I_{R} indicate the obtained left and right nodes by splitting the node I𝐼I. Then, it continues to split from the new constructed nodes until reaching the maximum depth of the tree. The node at the last layer is the tree leaf that represents the weight for the common instance in this node. The leaf weight w𝑤w is equivalent to the prediction of a new tree and contributes to the minimization of (4) through the term ft=wsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑤f_{t}=w. The optimal weight of each leaf is computed by

wj∗=−∑i∈Ijgi∑i∈Ijhi+λ,subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑗subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑗subscriptℎ𝑖𝜆w^{*}_{j}=-\frac{\sum_{i\in I_{j}}g_{i}}{\sum_{i\in I_{j}}h_{i}+\lambda}, (6)

where Ijsubscript𝐼𝑗I_{j} denotes the index set of instances that belong to the jt​hsuperscript𝑗𝑡ℎj^{th} leaf, i.e., Ij={i|q​(xi)=j}subscript𝐼𝑗conditional-set𝑖𝑞subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗I_{j}=\{i|q(x_{i})=j\}. As can be seen from (5) and (6), the tree construction requires the following knowledge:

  • •

    The possible splitting options to construct new nodes, i.e. IL,IRsubscript𝐼𝐿subscript𝐼𝑅I_{L},~{}I_{R}.

  • •

    The gradient and hessian values to evaluate the splitting options and compute the optimal weight.

2.2 Federated Learning over vertically partitioned data

The study by Yang et al. (2019a) introduces various settings of FL. In this study, our proposed protocols focus on FL over vertically partitioned data, in which multiple databases own different features of the same sample instances. To clarify the settings, we introduce the concept of Active Party and Passive Party proposed by Cheng et al. (2019) through the following definition

Definition 1.

Active Party and Passive Party

  • •

    Active Party (AP): The party that holds both feature data and the class label.

  • •

    Passive Party (PP): The data provider party, which has only the feature data.

The protocol studied by Liang and S.Chawathe (2004) is applied to determine the common database intersection between participants and align the features and class label with the corresponding sample ID securely. The main concern of XGBoost under this configuration is how to conduct the training process jointly between participants with the aligned database.

2.3 Secure Multi-party Computation (SMC)

Cramer et al. (2015) defines SMC as techniques that allow multiple participants to compute accurately the final output without revealing private information. SMC protocols require the participants to follow a particular procedure that leads to the final result and guarantee under some assumptions that the private data can not be reconstructed. The SMC protocol applied in this paper is the Secure Matrix Multiplication (SMM) protocol motivated by Karr et al. (2007) as follows

Protocol 1.

Secure Matrix Multiplication by Karr et al. (2007)
Let the parties A and B possess the private data matrix DA∈ℝn×msuperscriptDAsuperscriptℝnmD^{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m} and DB∈ℝn×lsuperscriptDBsuperscriptℝnlD^{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times l}, respectively. They want to obtain the result S=(DA)T​DB∈ℝm×lSsuperscriptsuperscriptDATsuperscriptDBsuperscriptℝmlS=(D^{A})^{T}D^{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times l} without knowing the private information of the other participant.

  1. 1.

    Party A finds the set 𝒰={ui∈ℝn|(DA)T​ui=0}𝒰conditional-setsubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptsuperscript𝐷𝐴𝑇subscript𝑢𝑖0\mathcal{U}=\{u_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}|(D^{A})^{T}u_{i}=0\}, which contains orthonormal null space vectors of (DA)Tsuperscriptsuperscript𝐷𝐴𝑇(D^{A})^{T}. Then it selects r𝑟r kernel vectors to construct the matrix Z=[u1​⋯​ur]∈ℝn×r𝑍delimited-[]subscript𝑢1⋯subscript𝑢𝑟superscriptℝ𝑛𝑟Z=[u_{1}\cdots u_{r}]\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times r}. We have

    (DA)T​Z=0m×rsuperscriptsuperscript𝐷𝐴𝑇𝑍superscript0𝑚𝑟(D^{A})^{T}Z=\textbf{0}^{m\times r}
  2. 2.

    Party A sends the matrix Z𝑍Z to party B, then party B computes the matrix W∈ℝn×l𝑊superscriptℝ𝑛𝑙W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times l} as

    W=(In×n−Z​ZT)​DB𝑊superscript𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇superscript𝐷𝐵W=(I^{n\times n}-ZZ^{T})D^{B}
  3. 3.

    Party B sends W𝑊W back to party A to compute the true result of the multiplication by

    (DA)T​W=(DA)T​(In×n−Z​ZT)​DB=(DA)T​DBsuperscriptsuperscript𝐷𝐴𝑇𝑊superscriptsuperscript𝐷𝐴𝑇superscript𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇superscript𝐷𝐵superscriptsuperscript𝐷𝐴𝑇superscript𝐷𝐵(D^{A})^{T}W=(D^{A})^{T}(I^{n\times n}-ZZ^{T})D^{B}=(D^{A})^{T}D^{B}

    ∎

The designed protocol assumes that all participants are semi-honest, i.e., they honestly follow the protocol but they are curious about the private data of other participants. The private data can not be uniquely reconstructed from the data exchange of Z,W𝑍𝑊Z,~{}W in step 2 and 3 thanks to the rank deficiency of the linear equation systems.

We first formulate the challenge of XGBoost under FL settings as a SMC problem that can be solved by SMM in section 3.2. Then we point out in section 3.3.1.2 and 3.3.2.2 that the potential privacy threat if the introduced protocol is directly applied. Afterward, we propose our protocol, FedXGBoost-SMM, which enhances the degree of privacy-preserving.

2.4 Differential Privacy (DP) & Local Differential Privacy (LDP)

Different from SMC techniques, Differential Privacy by Dwork and Roth (2014) guarantees privacy-preserving by introducing deniability in the private data. Informally, DP mechanisms inject calibrated noise into the query of the private dataset to make each individual’s data indistinguishable.

Definition 2.

Differential Privacy, Dwork and Roth (2014)
A randomized algorithm ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy if for any data sets x𝑥x and y𝑦y differing on at most one element and all 𝒮∈Range​(M)𝒮Range𝑀\mathcal{S}\in\text{Range}(M):

P​r​(ℳ​(x)∈𝒮)≤e​x​p​(ϵ)​P​r​(ℳ​(y)∈𝒮)𝑃𝑟ℳ𝑥𝒮𝑒𝑥𝑝italic-ϵ𝑃𝑟ℳ𝑦𝒮Pr(\mathcal{M}(x)\in\mathcal{S})\leq exp(\epsilon)Pr(\mathcal{M}(y)\in\mathcal{S})

A stronger DP approach is Local Differential Privacy, which perturbs the individual’s data locally to protect the private information.

Definition 3.

Local Differential Privacy, Úlfar Erlingsson et al. (2014)
The perturbation mechanism π(.)\pi(.) satisfies ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon- local differential privacy if for any two input t,t′𝑡superscript𝑡′t,~{}t^{\prime} in the domain of π(.)\pi(.) and any output t∗superscript𝑡t^{*} in the range of π(.)\pi(.), there is an ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 that

P​r​[π​(t)=t∗]≤e​x​p​(ϵ)​P​r​[π​(t′)=t∗]𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝜋𝑡superscript𝑡𝑒𝑥𝑝italic-ϵ𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝜋superscript𝑡′superscript𝑡Pr[\pi(t)=t^{*}]\leq exp(\epsilon)Pr[\pi(t^{\prime})=t^{*}]

Many efficient DP and LDP perturbation mechanisms that enable statistical analysis of perturbed data are studied in Duchi et al. (2013), Wang et al. (2019). In comparison to SMC techniques, LDP methods offer efficient computational costs because the perturbed data can be used directly in the analysis. However, due to the injected noise, the model accuracy is negatively impacted. This motivates us to design FedXGBoost-LDP, which is a heuristic approach that finds the compromise between model complexity and accuracy.

Remark 1.

The two protocols, FedXGBoost-SMM and FedXGBoost-LDP, are independent of each other. FedXGBoost-SMM is a theoretical approach applied linear algebra techniques to achieve the lossless property. FedXGBoost-LDP is a heuristic approach that conducts regression training with noise perturbed data. In principle, FedXGBoost-LDP is faster, and with small theoretical modification to increase the accuracy.

3 Main Results

To construct the new tree nodes, passive parties first (PP) analyze their user’s distribution according to their feature data. They they propose splitting candidates that separate the current node (the set of users being analyzed) into left and right nodes. The distribution analysis over a large data set is executed by the efficient Approximate Quantile algorithms as studied in Karnin et al. (2016), Li et al. (2008), Tyree et al. (2011). Afterward, the optimal splitting candidate is determined by comparing the loss reduction between splitting candidates as shown in (5). For brevity, in XGBoost under FL settings, PP plays a role as a splitting candidate owner. On the other side, the active party with the private class label owns the confidential gradient and hessian values of users. During the regression learning, AP and PP desire to compute the optimal splitting candidate securely.

Remark 2.

The description of the Approximate Quantile algorithm to analyze the users’ distribution and propose splitting candidates are introduced in Chen and Guestrin (2016). Note that we apply the trivial Quantile algorithm instead of the Weighted Quantile Sketch.

We introduce the concept of the splitting operator and splitting matrix to formulate the private information of the passive parties as follows

3.1 Splitting Matrix - Private Data of Passive Parties

We simplify the notations during the formulation by considering only one AP that has the true label of users, and one PP that constructs the splitting matrix based from one feature. The complete procedure for multiple PP with many features are described in section 4.

Each column of the splitting matrix represents one splitting candidate, which labels any user as ”1” if they belong to the left node and ”0” for the right node. Figure 1 and the following example depicts the functionality of the splitting operator and the splitting matrix.

Example 1.

According to (5), the evaluation of each splitting candidates require the aggregated gradients and hessians of instances in the left and right nodes. These are computed through the multiplication of the splitting matrix and the data vector. Particularly, let i∈{1​⋯​n}𝑖1⋯𝑛i\in\{1\cdots n\} denote the user index, 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} indicate the set of all users being analyzed and n=|𝒩|𝑛𝒩n=|\mathcal{N}|. The two subsets 𝒩L,𝒩Rsubscript𝒩𝐿subscript𝒩𝑅\mathcal{N}_{L},\mathcal{N}_{R} are obtained by the splitting operator, such that 𝒩L∩𝒩R=∅,𝒩L∪𝒩R=𝒩formulae-sequencesubscript𝒩𝐿subscript𝒩𝑅subscript𝒩𝐿subscript𝒩𝑅𝒩\mathcal{N}_{L}\cap\mathcal{N}_{R}=\varnothing,~{}\mathcal{N}_{L}\cup\mathcal{N}_{R}=\mathcal{N}. Let the gradient and hessian vector of n𝑛n users with numerical values be

g=(g1​⋯​gn)T,h=(h1​⋯​hn)T∈ℝnformulae-sequence𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑔1⋯subscript𝑔𝑛𝑇ℎsuperscriptsubscriptℎ1⋯subscriptℎ𝑛𝑇superscriptℝ𝑛g=(g_{1}\cdots g_{n})^{T},h=(h_{1}\cdots h_{n})^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}

From the set 𝒮={s1,⋯,sl}𝒮subscript𝑠1⋯subscript𝑠𝑙\mathcal{S}=\{s_{1},\cdots,s_{l}\} that represents l𝑙l splitting candidates, we use the index sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} to indicate one particular candidate. The aggregated gradients and hessians of users in the left and right nodes, which are GLsuperscript𝐺𝐿G^{L}, HLsuperscript𝐻𝐿H^{L} and GRsuperscript𝐺𝑅G^{R}, HRsuperscript𝐻𝑅H^{R} respectively, are computed from M,g,h𝑀𝑔ℎM,g,h as follows

After obtaining the result of the matrix multiplication, each candidate sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} is then evaluated by comparing the splitting score ℒs​p​l​i​tsisubscriptsuperscriptℒsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑠𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑡\mathcal{L}^{s_{i}}_{split} from (5). The best candidate s∗superscript𝑠s^{*} has the highest splitting score.

s∗=arg⁡maxsi∈𝒮⁡ℒs​p​l​i​tsi=arg⁡maxsi∈𝒮⁡12​[(GsiL)2(HsiL)+λ+(GsiR)2(HsiR)+λ−G2H+λ]−γsuperscript𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝒮subscriptsuperscriptℒsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑠𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑡subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝒮12delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐺𝐿subscript𝑠𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝐻𝐿subscript𝑠𝑖𝜆superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐺𝑅subscript𝑠𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝐻𝑅subscript𝑠𝑖𝜆superscript𝐺2𝐻𝜆𝛾\begin{split}s^{*}&=\arg\max_{s_{i}\in\mathcal{S}}\mathcal{L}^{s_{i}}_{split}\\ &=\arg\max_{s_{i}\in\mathcal{S}}\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{(G^{L}_{s_{i}})^{2}}{(H^{L}_{s_{i}})+\lambda}+\frac{(G^{R}_{s_{i}})^{2}}{(H^{R}_{s_{i}})+\lambda}-\frac{G^{2}}{H+\lambda}\right]-\gamma\end{split} (8)

If a splitting operator constructs the last layer of the tree, i.e., it constructs the tree leaves, the optimal weight for each leaf is computed by (6) as

wL∗=−Gs∗LHs∗L+λ,wR∗=−Gs∗RHs∗R+λ\begin{split}w^{*}_{L}&=-\frac{G^{L}_{s^{*}}}{H^{L}_{s^{*}}+\lambda},\quad w^{*}_{R}=-\frac{G^{R}_{s^{*}}}{H^{R}_{s^{*}}+\lambda}\end{split}
Remark 3.

The previous studies use the addition operation to compute the aggregated gradients and hessians between multiple parties. We instead introduce the splitting matrix to mathematically formulate the private data and the functionality of the PP.

3.2 Problem formulation - The relation between
FedXGBoost and Secure-Matrix Multiplication

From the concept of the splitting matrix, we reformulate the challenges of FedXGBoost into an SMC problem that can be solved by SMM protocols. Particularly, according to (7), the AP has g,h𝑔ℎg,~{}h, while the PPs own M𝑀M and they desire to compute MT​g,MT​hsuperscript𝑀𝑇𝑔superscript𝑀𝑇ℎM^{T}g,~{}M^{T}h securely. Then the results are applied to (7) and (8) to find the best splitting candidate and the optimal leaf weights. Figure 2 illustrates the concept. The next subsections use the introduced notations of M∈{0,1}n×l,g,h∈ℝnformulae-sequence𝑀superscript01𝑛𝑙𝑔ℎsuperscriptℝ𝑛M\in\{0,1\}^{n\times l},g,h\in\mathbb{R}^{n} to design two secure protocols, which are FedXGBoost-SMM and FedXGBoost-LDP, and analyze the information leakage of these two protocols.

Remark 4.

The two protocols FedXGBoost-SMM & FedXGBoost-LDP are independent and only different in their applied privacy-preserving techniques that allow the splitting scores to be evaluated securely. Therefore, we focus on analyzing this most crucial step, which determines the best splitting candidate. Additionally, the protocols are designed for semi-honest participants.

3.3 FedXGBoost-SMM

FedXGBoost-SMM is motivated by the SMM protocols that allow the participants to determine the optimal splitting candidate securely. We design two versions of FedXGBoost-SMM procedures that consider the different roles of AP and PP according to Protocol 1. The first version (FedXGBoost-SMM-1) considers DAsuperscript𝐷𝐴D^{A} as the gradient and the hessian g,h𝑔ℎg,~{}h vectors of the AP or combined as a matrix [g​h]∈ℝn×2delimited-[]𝑔ℎsuperscriptℝ𝑛2[g~{}h]\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 2}, while DBsuperscript𝐷𝐵D^{B} is the splitting matrix of PP. Conversely, in the second version (FedXGBoost-SMM-2), DAsuperscript𝐷𝐴D^{A} represents the splitting matrix of PP and DBsuperscript𝐷𝐵D^{B} indicates [g​h]delimited-[]𝑔ℎ[g~{}h] of AP.

Remark 5.

Even though the roles of parties are not important in the original SMM protocol, we point out in the privacy-leakage analysis that the potential threat of FedXGBoost-SMM-1 and FedXGBoost-SMM-2 are different. In general, FedXGBoost-SMM-1 achieves equivalent privacy-preserving as SecureBoost in Cheng et al. (2019) using homomorphic encryption technique. Nevertheless, under the assumption that any extreme curious party has unbounded computational capability, the private data of PPs in both SecureBoost and FedXGBoost-SMM-1 can be reconstructed. Motivated by this, the designed FedXGBoost-SMM-2 prevents the private data from being inferred with high confidence. This explains why FedXGBoost-SMM-2 requires sophisticated privacy-preserving but results in higher complexity.

3.3.1 FedXGBoost-SMM-1

3.3.1.1   Protocol description

Algorithm 1 describes the procedure of FedXGBoost-SMM-1. AP first determines the set of users being analyzed. Then it announces this set to all PP and transmits the generated orthonormal null-space vectors of [g​h]T∈ℝn×2superscriptdelimited-[]𝑔ℎ𝑇superscriptℝ𝑛2[g~{}h]^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 2}. Each PP analyzes the feature of the announced user set and constructs its private splitting matrix. Then it applies Algorithm 2 to generate a secure response W∈ℝn×l𝑊superscriptℝ𝑛𝑙W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times l}. The AP requests W𝑊W from all PP to compute the aggregated gradients and hessians of each splitting candidate, which are the elements of WT​g,WT​h∈ℝlsuperscript𝑊𝑇𝑔superscript𝑊𝑇ℎsuperscriptℝ𝑙W^{T}g,~{}W^{T}h\in\mathbb{R}^{l}. Afterward, it computes the splitting score and finds the optimal score between all PP. The PP with optimal score is requested to reveal the corresponding splitting operation. The AP then constructs new nodes and repeats the process with the new set of users.

3.3.1.2   Analysis of privacy-preserving

The study of SecureBoost provides a thorough analysis of potential privacy leakage for the AP. In our study, we focus on the private splitting matrix of the PPs. Despite these matrices do not contain the real feature data, they reveal the user’s distribution. Such information allows the curious party to infer the range of feature values. The potential privacy leakage of FedXGBoost-SMM-1 are caused by 1) The revealed null-space vectors set 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} of AP; 2) The response W𝑊W of PP; 3) AP knows the aggregated gradients and hessians of all splitting candidates;

  1. 1.

    PP knows the null-space vectors of AP
    Let the set of r𝑟r null-space vectors construct a matrix U∈ℝn×r𝑈superscriptℝ𝑛𝑟U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times r}, with r​a​n​k​(U)=r,r≤n−2formulae-sequence𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑘𝑈𝑟𝑟𝑛2rank(U)=r,~{}r\leq n-2, reconstructing [g​h]delimited-[]𝑔ℎ[g~{}h] is equivalent to the following problem

    Problem 1.

    Find x∈ℝn×2𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛2x\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 2} with a given U∈ℝn×r,rank​(U)=rformulae-sequence𝑈superscriptℝ𝑛𝑟rank𝑈𝑟U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times r},~{}\text{rank}(U)=r that satisfies

    UT​x=0r∈ℝrsuperscript𝑈𝑇𝑥superscript0𝑟superscriptℝ𝑟U^{T}x=0^{r}\in\mathbb{R}^{r} (9)

    There exist infinite solutions for (9) due to the rank deficiency of the linear equation system. The span of x𝑥x can be inferred if r≈n−2𝑟𝑛2r\approx n-2. However, it is sufficient to choose 1≪r≪n−2much-less-than1𝑟much-less-than𝑛21\ll r\ll n-2

  2. 2.

    AP knows the response W𝑊W from PP
    As described in the Algorithm 1, PP randomly selects r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} vectors in 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} to construct Z𝑍Z, with r′<rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}<r. Then it computes

    W=(In×n−Z​ZT)​M∈ℝn×l𝑊superscript𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇𝑀superscriptℝ𝑛𝑙W=(I^{n\times n}-ZZ^{T})M\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times l} (10)
    Property 1.

    Karr et al. (2007) The constructed Z from the received null-space vectors satisfies r​a​n​k​(In×n−Z​ZT)<n𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑘superscript𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇𝑛rank(I^{n\times n}-ZZ^{T})<n so it is not invertible.

    In the original protocol, Karr et al. (2007) stated that the information of r​a​n​k​(W)𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑘𝑊rank(W) contributes to the privacy leakage. For this reason, the randomness introduced in Algorithm 2 conceals the information of Z​ZT𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇ZZ^{T}.

  3. 3.

    AP knows the aggregated gradients and hessians of all splitting candidates
    Consider the AP is curious about M𝑀M. The effort to reconstruct possible splitting candidates is equivalent to the following integer programming problem

    Problem 2.

    Find {x1,⋯,xn}∈{0,1}subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛01\{x_{1},~{}\cdots,x_{n}\}\in\{0,1\} such that for a given A=(a1​⋯​an)T∈ℝn𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑛𝑇superscriptℝ𝑛A=(a_{1}~{}\cdots~{}a_{n})^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and b∈ℝ𝑏ℝb\in\mathbb{R} it satisfies

    ∑i=1nxi​ai−b=0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖𝑏0\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}a_{i}-b=0

    From our understanding, Problem 2 belongs to the set of NP-complete problems. This guarantees the privacy-preserving under the assumption of bounded computational capability. This challenge also occurs in methods applying homomorphic encryption techniques, yet was not mentioned in the previous literature. In SecureBoost, AP encrypts the gradients and hessians as ⟨g⟩,⟨h⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑔delimited-⟨⟩ℎ\left<g\right>,~{}\left<h\right>222⟨.⟩\left<.\right> operator indicates encrypted data before transmitting these to PP. Each PP aggregates the encrypted gradients and hessians and sends back to the AP, i.e., PP computes the multiplication of the splitting matrix and the encrypted vectors to obtain the encrypted ⟨MT​g⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑀𝑇𝑔\left<M^{T}g\right> and ⟨MT​h⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑀𝑇ℎ\left<M^{T}h\right>, respectively.

    Observation 1.

    If there exists an efficient algorithm that solves Problem 2 in polynomial time, the splitting matrix can be reconstructed from the known aggregated gradients ⟨MT​g⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑀𝑇𝑔\left<M^{T}g\right> and hessians ⟨MT​h⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑀𝑇ℎ\left<M^{T}h\right>.

To this end, we conclude that FedXGBoost-SMM-1 achieves equivalent privacy-preserving as SecureBoost that applies homomorphic encryption techniques. The open question from Observation 1 motivates us to design FedXGBoost-SMM-2.

3.3.2 FedXGBoost-SMM-2

3.3.2.1   FedXGBoost-SMM-2 - Protocol description

Algorithm 3 describes the procedure of FedXGBoost-SMM-2. From a given set of users, the PP analyzes the feature distribution and construct the splitting matrix M∈{0,1}n×l𝑀superscript01𝑛𝑙M\in\{0,1\}^{n\times l}. Then the PP applies Algorithm 4 to generate a quasi-secure splitting matrix M∗∈ℝn×l′superscript𝑀superscriptℝ𝑛superscript𝑙′M^{*}\in{\mathbb{R}^{n\times l^{\prime}}} and a set 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} that contains r𝑟r null-space vectors of (M∗)Tsuperscriptsuperscript𝑀𝑇(M^{*})^{T}, i.e., 𝒰={ui∈ℝn|(M∗)T​ui=0},|𝒰|=rformulae-sequence𝒰conditional-setsubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptsuperscript𝑀𝑇subscript𝑢𝑖0𝒰𝑟~{}\mathcal{U}=\{u_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}|(M^{*})^{T}u_{i}=0\},~{}|\mathcal{U}|=r. Algorithm 4 tackles the potential privacy leakage against curious party that has unbounded computational capability. The set 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} is then transmitted to the AP. The AP applies Algorithm 2 to construct a secure response W∈ℝn×2𝑊superscriptℝ𝑛2W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 2}. The PP requests W𝑊W from AP and computes (M∗)T​W∈ℝl′×2superscriptsuperscript𝑀𝑇𝑊superscriptℝsuperscript𝑙′2(M^{*})^{T}W\in\mathbb{R}^{l^{\prime}\times 2}. Then it applies a post-processing step to obtain (MT)​W∈ℝl×2superscript𝑀𝑇𝑊superscriptℝ𝑙2(M^{T})W\in\mathbb{R}^{l\times 2} that contains the aggregated gradients and hessians of each splitting candidate in each column respectively. To this end, the PP computes the splitting score of l𝑙l candidates according to (5) and determines the optimal one. Afterward, the PP sends the optimal score to the AP, which will be evaluated between multiple PPs. If the splitting option of each PP is selected, AP requests the splitting operation of that candidate (the specific column of the private splitting matrix), constructs new nodes, and repeats the process.

3.3.2.2   Analysis of privacy-preserving

The potential leakages are caused by  1) Algorithm 4: The null-space of the splitting matrix;  2) The optimal splitting candidate (one private column of the splitting matrix);  3) Algorithm 2: The result W𝑊W that PP requests from AP; We analyze the potential privacy leakage of the proposed FedXGBoost-SMM through the following mathematical arguments

  1. 1.

    AP knows the set of r𝑟r null-space vectors of matrix M∗superscript𝑀M^{*} generated by Algorithm 4.
    This potential leakage is similar to Problem 2 and it is the main motivation for FedXGBoost-SMM-2. We enhance the privacy of the splitting matrix by Algorithm 4. This algorithm adds calibrated random {0,1}01\{0,1\} columns before constructing the null-space, i.e.,

    M∗=[M​M′]∈{0,1}n×(l+l1)superscript𝑀delimited-[]𝑀superscript𝑀′superscript01𝑛𝑙subscript𝑙1M^{*}=[M~{}M^{\prime}]\in\{0,1\}^{n\times(l+l_{1})}

    , where M′∈{0,1}n×l1superscript𝑀′superscript01𝑛subscript𝑙1M^{\prime}\in\{0,1\}^{n\times l_{1}} is properly generated. If there exists an efficient algorithm as declared in the Observation 1, the private splitting label can not be inferred with high confidence. Figure 3 illustrates the concept of Algorithm 4. Note that these randomness do not affect the final result because the columns are independent from each other. The result from generated columns are omitted in the evaluation of splitting candidates. We conclude that the private splitting matrix is secured through the generated enhanced null-space.

  2. 2.

    AP knows the optimal splitting option.
    After the optimal splitting score is determined, AP requests the corresponding optimal splitting operation, which is one column of the private splitting matrix M𝑀M from the selected PP. Despite this column does not reveal any additional private information, it is the main reason that requires the random {0,1}01\{0,1\} columns in Algorithm 4 to be generated properly.

  3. 3.

    PP knows the W𝑊W generated by Algorithm 2 from the AP.
    In step 2 of the original SMM Protocol 1, the AP computes W𝑊W from the obtained Z𝑍Z from the PP as

    W=(In×n−Z​ZT)​V∈ℝn×2,𝑊superscript𝐼𝑛𝑛𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛2W=(I^{n\times n}-ZZ^{T})V\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 2}, (11)

    where V=[g​h]∈ℝn×2𝑉delimited-[]𝑔ℎsuperscriptℝ𝑛2V=[g~{}h]\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times 2} in our scenario. As guaranteed by Property 1, there exist infinite solutions for (11). However, if Z​ZT𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇ZZ^{T} is sparse that has rows with one element different from zero, the true values of V𝑉V for some users are observable. Indeed, this is a critical problem due to the property of the null-space of a categorical matrix. Briefly, the original splitting matrix M𝑀M has multiple rows that contain only 00 or 111. This causes the sparsity of the null-space vectors and the computed Z​ZT𝑍superscript𝑍𝑇ZZ^{T}. This is detectable by the AP so AP must refuse to compute W𝑊W.

    Remark 6.

    To handle this, Algorithm 4 adds columns with random numerical values to M𝑀M before generating the null-space vectors.

    M∗=[M​M′​Y]∈{0,1}n×(l+l1+l2)superscript𝑀delimited-[]𝑀superscript𝑀′𝑌superscript01𝑛𝑙subscript𝑙1subscript𝑙2M^{*}=[M~{}M^{\prime}~{}Y]\in\{0,1\}^{n\times(l+l_{1}+l_{2})}

    where Y∼𝒩​(μ,σ)∈ℝn×l2similar-to𝑌𝒩𝜇𝜎superscriptℝ𝑛subscript𝑙2Y\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma)\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times l_{2}}. Then AP applies Algorithm 2 to generate a secure response W𝑊W. Note that the columns of M∗superscript𝑀M^{*} are independent so the multiplication result of columns in M′superscript𝑀′M^{\prime} and Y𝑌Y are omitted in the final evaluation.

From the analysis, we conclude that FedXGBoost-SMM-2 satisfies the privacy-preserving constraints. Furthermore, it is more secure than SecureBoost and FedXGBoost-SMM-1 under the assumption that the curious party has unbounded computational capability.

3.4 FedXGBoost-LDP

FedXGBoost-LDP is a different approach from FedXGBoost-SMM that perturbs the gradients and hessians to achieve privacy-preserving, e.g from Duchi et al. (2013), Piecewise or Hybrid mechanisms from Wang et al. (2019), etc. The perturbed data is then used directly for training, which reduces the training time in comparison to HE or SMM methods. Nevertheless, due to the high nonlinearity of the splitting score function, the injected noise degrades the utility strongly. For this reason, we use the first-order approximation for (4) to evaluate the splitting score. Appendix A depicts that the first-order approximation offers an unbiased estimator for the splitting score, and the optimal splitting candidate from the set 𝒮={s1,⋯,sl}𝒮subscript𝑠1⋯subscript𝑠𝑙\mathcal{S}=\{s_{1},~{}\cdots,~{}s_{l}\} is determined as

s∗=arg⁡maxsi∈𝒮−1λ​GsiL​GsiRsuperscript𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝒮1𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝐺𝐿subscript𝑠𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐺𝑅subscript𝑠𝑖\begin{split}s^{*}&=\arg\max_{s_{i}\in\mathcal{S}}-\frac{1}{\lambda}G^{L}_{s_{i}}G^{R}_{s_{i}}\end{split} (12)

Appendix A also depicts that the variance of the evaluation depends strongly on the variance of the injected noise, which implies a compromise between privacy and the accuracy. Nevertheless, this method accelerate the training process significantly in comparison to encryption or linear algebra techniques, thus it is evaluated as an heuristic approach. Procedure 5 describes how the best splitting score is estimated by FedXGBoost-LDP. The procedure is similar to the plain XGBoost, the only difference is the regression training uses g∗,h∗superscript𝑔superscriptℎg^{*},h^{*} and evaluates the splitting candidates by (12).

4 The complete FedXGBoost Protocols - FedXGBoost-SMM & FedXGBoost-LDP

Firstly, the AP determines the set of users (the users in a common node) being analyzed and announces this to all PPs. Next, all parties follow either FedXGBoost-SMM or FedXGBoost-LDP to find the best splitting candidate. After determining optimal splitting score, AP requests the information from the owner of the best score. Particularly, AP requests the feature analyzed by that splitting operation and the set of users in left and right nodes. After receiving the feature information, AP constructs a look-up table to record the corresponding PP and the analyzed feature. On the other side, the chosen PP also records the chosen feature and the best splitting operation for the usage in the regression phase. The training process continues from the split users’ space until the tree reaches the maximum depth. At this stage, optimal leaf weight is computed according to (6) and saved for the prediction phase. This completes the construction of one regression tree.

The application of the regression of the trained model is similar to the study by Cheng et al. (2019). When the AP wants to make inference from a new instance, it uses its look-up table and cooperates with the PPs to determine in which tree leaf the instance belongs to. Next, it aggregates the optimal weight overall regression trees to obtain a final prediction.

5 Experiments and Evaluation

We provide the experiments on two dataset 1) ”Give Me Some Credit” 333https://www.kaggle.com/c/GiveMeSomeCredit and 2) ”Default of Credit Card Clients” 444https://www.kaggle.com/uciml/default-of-credit-card-clients-dataset published on Kaggle. The first dataset contains the data of 150000 users with 10 attributes. The second dataset contains the data of 30000 users with 25 attributes. The experiments are conducted by two 16-cpu-core 64GB-memory Linux machines with network bandwidth of 25000Mb/s. Leverage Apache Spark platform is applied for distributed computing. We evaluate FedXGBoost-LDP by comparing the model accuracy and the time consumption with the plain XGBoost and the studied encryption techniques. FedXGBoost applies different LDP perturbation techniques, which are Laplace mechanism (LM) from Dwork and Roth (2014) and Duchi’s method (DM) from Duchi et al. (2013) with varying privacy budget ϵ={1,3}italic-ϵ13\epsilon=\{1,3\}. According to (12), we also evaluate LDP mechanisms using first-order approximation, which is expected to reduce the accuracy loss by the injected noise.

Figure 4 and 5 depict the loss trajectory of two experiments. As can be seen from figure 5(b), despite the injected noise cause a small performance reduction, the loss convergence is equivalent to the plain XGBoost. Table 1 and 2 evaluate the time consumption of different approaches. In general, LDP methods have negligible overhead in comparison with plain XGBoost. Compared with encryption method, it tremendously accelerate the training process.

6 Conclusion

This paper studies two different protocols (FedXGBoost-SMM and FedXGBoost-LDP) that enable the state of the art tree ensemble model XGBoost to be conducted under FL settings. Different from the previous work applying homomorphic encryption, our linear algebra based protocol FedXGBoost-SMM incurs lower overhead while maintaining lossless accuracy. We also propose and empirically evaluate the accuracy of the heuristic protocol FedXGBoost-LDP, which relaxes the splitting score computation to first order approximation for computational speedup, and uses LDP noise perturbation. For future work, we will experimentally evaluate the overhead of FedXGBoost-SMM. Further study of scalable privacy-preserving XGBoost for FL is crucial for its deployment in practice.

Appendix A Unbiased splitting score estimation by using first-order approximation for the regression objective

Due to the high nonlinearity of (4), the noise injected gradients and hessians is expected to degrade the regression learning strongly. This appendix depicts that if we apply the first-order approximation for the regression objective, we can use an unbiased estimator to evaluate the noisy splitting score.
